content.text: Deliver the Canada Person ID as a table in Redshift, based on the logic created by the Analytics team

The Transaction Monitoring Process for AML purposes for Canada has to be able to mirror the process for US, capturing the transactions and generating alerts based on the rules we have designed. The transactions will be analyzed on a post-transaction basis and "offline", feeding a table in the data lake. Same rules utilized for the US program will be used for Canada
We are trying to solve the lack of single unique identifier for Canada, as we have SSN for US. For that we need to leverage NAME + DOB as mentioned above to create the Canada ID for consumers.
We need this information to be at some table in the data lake and updated on a daily basis at 3 AM PST so we can query and generate AML alerts.
This needs to be created for every customer (every
Also we need this to be implemented by 12/15/2023.

fields.summary: Implement Canada Person ID solution for CAN Merchants for AML Program

content.text: In recent days, I have observed a recurring occurrence of Bamboo elastic agents disconnecting during pipeline execution, which has negatively impacted team operations across the company. This problem appears intermittently. Analysis of Bamboo Server logs turned out to be limited, as when an agent goes offline, it shuts down and no logs are retained.

In an attempt to identify the source of this problem, I analyzed the virtual machine (VM) metrics, and AWS CloudWatch indicated a significant spike in disk reads (EBS), followed by the instance being terminated (offline).

To understand the complexity and recurring of the Dev Support tasks, It was combined to create an issue to document which Dev Support tasks were done. The main purpose of this issue is to evidence operation procedures that use much time in the DevOps team to address automation and flow changes with other teams.
Document the Dev-Support Tasks done in the Sprint of the Issue Title (only by this Issue Assignee)
Create a comment on this issue with a table. Must be the following columns in the table:
: Category of the Dev Support. The main categories are:

content.text: Analytics Team will execute some tests in our DATA-DEV environment on QuickSight, and their access there is IAM-ANALYTICS-ADMIN, which does not have the same policy attached as in IamAnalyticsPermissionSet, which does not make much sense.
We also need to change some permissions related to redshift.
Here is how it should look like:

IamAnalyticsAdminPermissionSet:
    Type: 'AWS::SSO::PermissionSet'
    Description: IAM-ANALYTICS-ADMIN PermissionSet
    Properties:
      InstanceArn: !Ref ssoarnid
      Name: IAM-ANALYTICS-ADMIN
      Description: IAM-ANALYTICS-ADMIN PermissionSet
      SessionDuration: PT12H
      CustomerManagedPolicyReferences:
      - Name: 'data-quicksight-author'

content.text: We gotta be more active in terms of query monitoring on all of our redshift clusters. This monitoring can be done with Redshift internal management views, however those views will hold only 7 days worth of data.
It is important that we persist those views for a longer period as well as creating metrics over those. The whole idea here is to:
better understand which views are the most important
create analytics models to identify non optimal query plans (data shuffling, spill disk usage, queue waiting time, effective execution time, etc.)
Confluence page documenting most relevant management views on Redshift
DBT models for data persistence to be executed on all clusters
DBT models for data transformation so we can come up with metrics for query analysis

fields.summary: Persist Redshift Internal Views for Query Monitoring

content.text: The WAF integration on Admin Console was finally implemented and went to production on the latest application release.
Unfortunately, due to a new verification (IPs must be in CIDR format) and the fact that were already a bunch of IPs saved on the database that not comply to this rule,
we cannot edit/add/delete new merchant IPs
To resolve that, we must delete all merchants IPs or update them to CIDR format directly on the database.
I did a simple query to get a grasp of the trouble and here is the result:
Delete all Merchants IPs from database or;
Sanitize and update all IPs to CIDR format.
QUERY TO EXECUTE ON PWMB DATABASE

-- 11 rows impacted
update pwmb.pwmb_merchants set ip_list = ';', updated_at = now() where ip_list <> '' and ip_list <> ';';

fields.summary: Sanitize Merchants IPs on AMER-PRO Database

content.text: As we have seen an increased load on our DataOps Redshift cluster, we thought isolating workloads once again in a Serverless instance would be a good idea.

Spin up a serverless cluster and test the data quality procedure on it.
Get the execution metrics and compare them to the current one.
Have a final decision about rolling out this approach. If yes, create a Jira issue with a proper description.
Create a confluence page contemplating the outcomes.

content.text: Android Server is now an all-in-one EC2 instance. Due to that, we should find a new way to deploy on top of EC2 instances.
Build pipeline continues the same, and pass through the new Docker image tag, generate both ARM and AMD images
The pipeline generates an EC2 metadata script with the new image, which runs a sed to substitute the old tag using the new tag
Use terraform apply to rollout the change
This will trigger and EC2 instance refresh, the new instance will come up, download the APKs, configure frida, start the application with the new image tag, register with ALB and serve traffic
Use awscli to check instance refresh status

content.text: Today we must decide how to automate the entire Backstage pipeline, from Github to Bamboo and then to ArgoCD. There are many open questions, E.g. how to trigger the Bamboo plans how we will control development on GitHub branches, and how we’ll control the release process.
We should explore possibilities and different setups to achieve an entire automated pipeline flow.
By the end of this issue, we need at least the first version of that process with all considerations about any decision taken and possible blockers that can arise during the process.
All information should be on Jira/Confluence

content.text: Strength Cloud Security by implementing new feature from GuardDuty named EKS Runtime Monitoring.

All environments running this new GuardDuty feature.

– Provides runtime threat detection for Amazon EKS nodes and containers within your AWS environment. With the support of an Amazon EKS add-on GuardDuty security agent, EKS Runtime Monitoring monitors and processes runtime events for your Amazon EKS clusters to identify potential security threats in your environment.

Create an initial template for Terraform following our code best practices.
Validate the idea with new team members and collect feedback to improve the template or create new issues for it.
Feel free to reach out to any other team member to collect insights and refine this V1 template for Terraform.

It will elevate the visibility of errors where identified, and provide drill down about the deployments, pods, and other objects for a service.[

content.text: The Backstage Software Catalog is a centralized system that keeps track of ownership and metadata for all the software in your ecosystem (services, websites, libraries, data pipelines, etc). The catalog is built around the concept of
stored together with the code, which are then harvested and visualized in Backstage. [

The reference page contains all core concepts well described, but more than how to make it work technically, we need to push it forward and think about how it could bring us more value. Consider this example scenario:

A new member just arrived on our team, and he doesn’t know where our code is, how to find our tools, why we chose this or that, or even what kind of pattern we use for every tool we use, E.g Terraform, Argocd, Spinnaker, even developer support actions. For sure, everybody from our team struggled a lot during the initial period and even today we still feel some sort of difficulty in a few areas. So let’s imagine what we could do to make those hard times smoother in the way our new team member can perform well quickly and keep focusing on things that bring value to our company, not wasting time on things that he shouldn’t.
We need to create a demo for the engineering team showing how valuable this feature could be when close to a real scenario. Exploring all possibilities.
Focus on these two modules: Merchant Gateway and Fi Gateway;
Besides exploring this demo setup, users should be able to customize and interact with components. So, this issue has a linked dependency on our CI/CD pipeline.
All information should be on Jira/Confluence

incompatible with provisioner "processor", daemonset overhead={"cpu":"1160m","memory":"1089577728","pods":"12"}, did not tolerate role=processor:NoSchedule; incompatible with provisioner "services-arm", daemonset overhead={"cpu":"960m","memory":"963748608","pods":"10"}, did not tolerate role=services-arm:NoSchedule; incompatible with provisioner "sftp", daemonset overhead={"cpu":"960m","memory":"963748608","pods":"10"}, did not tolerate role=sftp:NoSchedule; incompatible with provisioner "others", daemonset overhead={"cpu":"1060m","memory":"984720128","pods":"11"}, incompatible requirements, key role, role In [neo4j] not in role In [others]; incompatible with provisioner "neo4j", daemonset overhead={"cpu":"960m","memory":"963748608","pods":"10"}, no instance type satisfied resources {"cpu":"1960m","memory":"13848650496","pods":"11"} and requirements karpenter.sh/capacity-type In [on-demand], karpenter.sh/provisioner-name In [neo4j], kubernetes.io/arch In [arm64], kubernetes.io/os In [linux], node.kubernetes.io/instance-type In [r7g.large], role In [neo4j], topology.kubernetes.io/zone In [us-west-2c] (no instance type which had enough resources and the required offering met the scheduling requirements); incompatible with provisioner "frontend", daemonset overhead={"cpu":"1160m","memory":"1089577728","pods":"12"}, did not tolerate role=frontend:NoSchedule    {"commit": "34d50bf-dirty", "pod": "pwmb-data/neo4j-server-01-0"}
Karpenter basically says… With these 11 pods from DaemonSets, you have XYZ resources left and this does not accomodate your pod. The pod gets stuck on Pending state and causes many issues.
Remove the unneeded DaemonSets from the cluster (.e.g

Double-check memory and cpu requests and reduce as much as we can
Tested on AMER-DEV and merged into main

Investigate Redirection via Arbitrary Host Header Manipulation vulnerability detected by Halo Security tool.
Host header injection is a security vulnerability that occurs when an attacker manipulates the Host header in an HTTP request to inject malicious data.
Attackers can redirect users to malicious content, deface websites, or trick users into disclosing sensitive information through phishing attacks.
Implementing proper validation and sanitization of input headers is essential to mitigate the risks of Host header injection.

content.text: Currently FIC Server standalone deployments use the same Spinnaker deploy pipeline as the other apps.
While this works, it has a few drawbacks:
1 - Changes to the main pipeline need to be tested being called from both bamboo deploy pipelines
2 - Optimizations or step removals that aren’t required when deployed a single module cannot be put in place because the pipeline is shared

3 - Errors firing the pipeline with all apps could accidentally trigger a deploy of other PWMB apps that aren’t actually present on the image tag being deployed, due to it only containing the War file for fic-server
4 - Execution history is shared with the main pipeline which make refreshes unnecessarily error prone when one needs to check 3 image tags before deploying
Create Spinnaker pipeline to deploy a single app from a different image, using a new manifest
Pipeline template to deploy a single app created
Pipeline created from this template working and tested on the DEV environment

content.text: A couple occurrences of environment change requests happened recently where the requester asked to change an environment variable that they shouldn’t be allowed to change because they are generated or managed by the DevSecOps team.

These variables are not usually secrets, but occasionally other variables such as service URL’s, DB connection, AWS params and other strings which should only be changed only after careful verification and subsequent monitoring.
If those were on their dedicated files, one could more easily identify if the variable should or not be changed by the development team and reject or confirm the change with the DevOps team.
List all env vars that are exclusively managed by DevOps, secrets or not
Have all this variables made available to the application pods separately from the usual main.properties and passwd.properties file
Create a dedicated configmap for devops env vars that aren’t secrets
Create a dedicated secret for devops env vars that are secrets
Have these files mounted on all pods the same way that the main.properties and the passwd.properties file are made
